docs.lead_paragraph: Eldridge Lee, a real estate broker and adjunct college professor in Fairburn, Ga., found out that he had Type 2 diabetes more than a decade ago. But he did not take the disease seriously until two years ago, when sky-high blood pressure -- a complication of diabetes -- led to heart disease. ''After coming out of heart surgery, I was sitting with a ventilator down my throat and had a moment of realization that the diabetes, which I had pretty much been ignoring, had led to this problem with my heart,'' said Mr. Lee, 53, who now controls his blood pressure, cholesterol and blood sugar with diet, exercise and six drugs.

headline.main: New Message Emerges in Treating Diabetes

docs.abstract: Dr Allen F Shaughnessy, PinnacleHealth System (Harrisburg, Pa) medical education director, publishes study in BMJ, British medical journal, that identifies that managing hypertension is more critical to good health than glycemic control for people with type 2 diabetes; study finds that lower blood pressure in patients with type 2 diabetes leads to sizable reductions in death rates; American Diabetes Association has sponsored initiative to link diabetes care with heart disease and stroke, but concerns about multiple medications and life style changes for patients have thwarted large-scale change; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Eldridge Lee, a real estate broker and adjunct college professor in Fairburn, Ga., found out that he had Type 2 diabetes more than a decade ago. But he did not take the disease seriously until two years ago, when sky-high blood pressure -- a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some teenagers in Ohio got more than the high they were looking for when they consumed seeds from a moonflower, a close relative of jimson weed. The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published a report last week on the poisonings, which caused 14 teenagers to be hospitalized in the Cleveland and Akron areas last fall.
docs.abstract: Ohio teenagers, trying to get high, consume moonflower seeds and end up in hospital; Dr Robert Goetz of Cincinnati Drug and Poison Information Center reports some teens ate seeds while others drank tea brewed with seeds; contends that teenagers experienced hallucinogenic effects and extreme physical sickness; all 14 children who were hospitalized are fully recovered (S)
docs.snippet: Some teenagers in Ohio got more than the high they were looking for when they consumed seeds from a moonflower, a close relative of jimson weed.    The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published a report last week on the poisonings,...

keywords.value: CINCINNATI DRUG AND POISON INFORMATION CENTER

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers reported yesterday that there may be a link between some newer drugs prescribed for schizophrenia and a dangerous inflammation of the pancreas. The study, which looked at patients taking any of four antipsychotic drugs, examined all cases of pancreatitis that were reported to the Food and Drug Administration or written up in medical journals between January 1981 and February 2002. It found that more cases were associated with three newer drugs than with an older generation drug.

headline.main: Pancreatitis Risk Seen In Schizophrenia Drugs

docs.abstract: Dr P Murali Doraiswamy, Duke University division for biological psychiatry chief, authors report in journal Pharmacotherapy that outlines potential link between newer generation schizophrenia drugs and pancreatitis; contends that preliminary data show cause for concern, but holds that more research is needed to determine if increase in inflammation of pancreas is directly related to use of antipsychotics known as atypicals, or if those people with schizophrenia have other risk factors that may explain higher incidence of disease (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers reported yesterday that there may be a link between some newer drugs prescribed for schizophrenia and a dangerous inflammation of the pancreas.     The study, which looked at patients taking any of four antipsychotic drugs, examined all...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Big Blackout of 2003 was an eye-opener for many urbanites and suburbanites who had long taken electricity for granted and suddenly found themselves unprepared for a crisis that threatened their food and water supplies. And then there were those who discovered that they were unable to prepare what food they had, bathe or even wash their hands, flush the toilet, put gasoline in the car, go to places they had to go, entertain themselves and their children and, of course, see what they were doing after the sun had set.

headline.main: Making Life Go On When the Lights Go Off

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses preparedness for electrical outages at home and office; lists specific supplies to have at work and home and elements to have on hand that can make life without power more livable; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: The Big Blackout of 2003 was an eye-opener for many urbanites and suburbanites who had long taken electricity for granted and suddenly found themselves unprepared for a crisis that threatened their food and water supplies.    And then there were...

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people accept the idea that stress and depression chip away at the body's natural ability to fight off disease. But many medical scientists have remained skeptical that the mind can exert such a direct influence over the immune system. In recent years, however, evidence has accumulated that psychology can indeed affect biology. Studies have found, for example, that people who suffer from depression are at higher risk for heart disease and other illnesses. Other research has shown that wounds take longer to heal in women who care for patients with Alzheimer's disease than in other women who are not similarly stressed. And people under stress have been found to be more susceptible to colds and flu, and to have more severe symptoms after they fall ill.

headline.main: Power of Positive Thinking May Have a Health Benefit, Study Says

docs.abstract: Dr Richard J Davidson, University of Wisconsin Laboratory for Affective Neuroscience director, leads study published in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences that links mental state with ability of human immune system to fight off illness; study observed 52 women who were asked to relive extremely negative and positive moments in their lives and then were given flu vaccine; those reliving negative emotions, which stimulate brain's right prefrontal cortex, were found to produce lowest levels of antibodies; study contends that mood and emotion have some ability to modulate physical health; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: Most people accept the idea that stress and depression chip away at the body's natural ability to fight off disease. But many medical scientists have remained skeptical that the mind can exert such a direct influence over the immune system.    In...

docs.lead_paragraph: A number of studies have shown that chocolate contains a substance that can protect arteries. This research has led some experts to promote the idea that chocolate can be part of a healthy diet -- though others have argued that the extra calories from eating candy will offset any benefit. A new study, though, published last week in the journal Nature concludes that only dark chocolate has potential advantages. It examined levels of epicatechin, the antioxidant compound, one of a group of substances found in food known as flavonoids that have been linked to better cardiac health.
docs.abstract: University of Glasgow (Scotland) and Institute for Food and Nutrition Research (Rome) scientists, studying effects of chocolate on protecting human arteries, find eating dark chocolate significantly increases beneficial blood antioxidant levels; research, published in journal Nature, shows that milk contained within or ingested along with chocolate decreases its antioxidant levels; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A year after the American Academy of Pediatrics called on schools to end no-nits policies that keep children being treated for head lice out of classes, little has changed except the intensity of the debate, according to an article published yesterday in The American Journal of Nursing. The article said few schools had dropped their no-nits rules, even though the pediatrics academy had argued that the policy led some children to miss so much school that they were forced to repeat a grade.
docs.abstract: American Journal of Nursing article, published one year after American Academy of Pediatrics urged end to no-nits school policies, shows little has changed in treatment of children with head lice; Dr Barbara Frankowski, American Academy of Pediatrics chairwoman on school health and pediatrition, contends that controversial malady is inconvenient to treat and potentially embarrassing for parents and children, but poses no viable health threat to children (S)
docs.snippet: A year after the American Academy of Pediatrics called on schools to end no-nits policies that keep children being treated for head lice out of classes, little has changed except the intensity of the debate, according to an article published...

docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds too good to be true, and maybe it is. But companies are working on ways to eliminate unwanted fat from the body painlessly, without the invasiveness and side effects of liposuction. None of the techniques have been approved as safe or effective, but believers speak of making fat cells essentially melt away by using sound waves, electricity or injections of a fat-attacking substance.

headline.main: Doctors Without Scalpels: Seeking to Melt Fat Away

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence S Reed, Manhattan plastic surgeon on American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery committee to investigate new technology, tells of false leads in quest for new ways to perform cosmetic surgeries; liposuction, most common cosmetic surgery procedure, is challenged by several companies hoping to break down and remove fat in body without complications of surgery; use of ultrasound, electroporation and drug therapies as ways to improve appearance without surgery are discussed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Breakout Principle,'' by Dr. Herbert Benson and William Proctor. Scribner, $25. Rebecca, the subject of a case history in this self-help book, often found herself with writer's block. To break through what stood in her way of rescuing a character from a tight spot, she stopped work and walk-jogged to a favorite seaside locale.
docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School Dr Herbert Benson and William Proctor book Breakout Principledescribes concept of breakout mind-body relationship and ways to use triggers to activate life-altering revelations; uses case history to exemplify concepts; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fatigue and even a legally permissible amount of alcohol can combine dangerously for drivers, a British study has found, especially because the young men being tested appeared to be unaware of their increased impairment. After getting five hours of sleep, 12 men who had the equivalent of two glasses of beer with lunch drifted out of their lanes an average of 32 times in a simulated two-hour highway drive.
docs.abstract: Dr Jim Horne, Loughborough University (Liechestershire, Eng), leads research published in Occupational and Environmental Medicine, British Medical Association journal, that shows even legal amounts of alcohol combined with fatigue substantially increase risk of driving accidents; cartoon (S)
